go ahead.translation[0].definitions[0].d: used to tell someone they can do something
go ahead.translation[0].definitions[0].e: ‘Can I have the sports section?’ ‘Yeah, go ahead, I’ve read it.’
go ahead.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to do something that was planned, especially in spite of a problem
go ahead.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Frank’ll be late but we’ll go ahead with the meeting anyway.
go ahead.translation[0].definitions[2].e: Tests of anti-cancer drugs are to go ahead this year.
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to start to do something, especially after planning it or asking permission to do it
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[0].e: They’ve decided to go ahead with plans to build 50 new houses on the site.
I went ahead and arranged the trip anyway.
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[1].d: if an event or process goes ahead, it happens
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[1].e: A judge has ruled that the music festival can go ahead.
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[2].d: used to give someone permission to do something, or let them speak before you
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[2].e: ‘Do you mind if I open the window?’ ‘No, go ahead.’
If you want to leave, go right ahead.
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[3].d: to go somewhere before the other people in your group
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[3].e: You go ahead and we’ll catch you up later.
He stood back to let Sue go ahead of him.
go ahead.translation[1].definitions[4].d: to start to be winning a game or competition
go ahead.translation[3].definitions[0].d: using new methods or ideas and therefore likely to succeed
